Text saved: The Hunger Games is a very famous book. It is for teenagers and young people. Suzanne Collins is an American writer. She wrote the book. It came out in 2008. Many people have bought it. It is in 26 languages. It has sold millions of copies. It is the first book for young people to sell over a million copies on computers. Now, The Hunger Games is also a big film from Hollywood. The film is also very famous. It made 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend. This was only in North America.
Feedback received: Grade 9/10 - PASS

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6649 is below the required 0.75 threshold. The core message of the original text, which emphasizes the immense and comparable success of both the book and the film, has been significantly diluted. The original text uses strong phrases like 'hugely successful' and 'just as successful'. Your version breaks these concepts into many short, less impactful sentences, such as 'She wrote a very famous book', 'Many people read it', and 'The film is also very famous'. This fragmentation loses the strong, overarching sense of extraordinary success and the direct comparison between the book's and film's achievements. Suggestion: Rephrase to maintain the emphasis on the book's and film's significant success. Combine related ideas to convey the scale of achievement more directly, ensuring the comparative success is clearly stated.

Text saved: Suzanne Collins is an American writer. She wrote a very popular book. Its name is "The Hunger Games". This book is for teenagers and young people.

It came out in 2008. Many people bought it. It sold millions of copies. You can read it in 26 languages. It was the first book for young people to sell over a million copies on computers. This shows it is very successful.

Now, "The Hunger Games" is also a big film from Hollywood. The film is also very successful. It is as successful as the book. It made 152.5 million dollars in its first weekend. This was only in North America.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Deep Qualitative Audit - Vocabulary. The word 'hunger' is classified as B1, which is above the A2 standard.
